ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.0.1_0: Reverence to him, the Fortunate One, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naḷeru’s Nimba tree with a large sangha of five hundred monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.2_0: And a brahmin in Verañjā was told:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.3_0: “Sir, the ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, is staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naleru’s Nimba tree with a large sangha of five hundred monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.4_0: and about this dear Gotama this beautiful report has gone round:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.5_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.6_0: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.7_0: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.7_1: and explains the spiritual life which is complete, full and pure.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.8_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.1_0: Then the brahmin approached the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.1_2: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.3_0: that you don’t bow down to old brahmins, stand up for them, or offer them a seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.4_0: And this is indeed the case,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.4_1: for Master Gotama does not bow to old brahmins, elderly and senior, who are advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; nor does he rise in their presence or offer them a seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.6_0: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—for whom I should bow down or rise up or offer a seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.7_0: For if he does bow to him, rise in his presence, or offer him a seat.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.2_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m austere.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.3_0: For the Realized One has given up taste for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches. It’s cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.4_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.6_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m unlikeable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.7_0: For the liking of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and material objects has been abandoned by the Buddha, cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that it is incapable of reappearing.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.8_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.10_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that the ascetic Gotama teaches non-action.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.11_0: For I teach the non-doing of misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.12_0: I teach the non-doing of various kinds of bad and unwholesome actions.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.13_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.15_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that the ascetic Gotama is an annihilationist.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.16_0: For I speak of the annihilation of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.17_0: I speak of the annihilation of various sorts of bad, unwholesome qualities.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.18_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.20_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I am detestable.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.21_0: For I detest misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.22_0: I detest being possessed of various kinds of bad and unwholesome qualities.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.23_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.25_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m an exterminator.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.26_0: For I teach for the sake of the extermination of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.27_0: and the many kinds of unskillful things.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.28_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.30_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m austere.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.31_0: For I say that bad, unwholesome qualities—misconduct by body, speech, and mind—are to be disciplined.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.32_0: One who has abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined, who has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm-stump, done away with them so utterly that they are incapable of reappearing—such a one I call one who is austere.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.33_0: The Realized One is someone who has given up unskillful qualities that should be mortified. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so that they’re unable to arise in the future.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.34_0: But that’s not what you meant.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.36_0: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m austere.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.37_0: For one whose future conception in a womb, whose rebirth in a future life, is abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that one is incapable of reappearing—such a one I call one who is withdrawn.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.38_0: Now my future conception in a womb, my rebirth in a future life, has been abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that I’m incapable of reappearing.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.39_0: But that’s not what you meant.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.1_0: Brahmin, suppose there were a hen with eight or ten or twelve eggs,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.2_0: properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.3_0: Would the chick that is first to break out of the eggshell with its claws and beak and hatch safely?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.4_0: “Master Gotama, that should be called the eldest.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.5_0: for he’s the eldest of those.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.6_0: “Just so, in this deluded population, enveloped like an egg, I alone in the world have split the eggshell of delusion and reached the supreme full awakening.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.7_0: Now, brahmin, the elder in the world,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.1_0: I was firmly energetic and had clarity of mindfulness; my body was tranquil and my mind unified.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.2_0: Fully secluded from the five senses, secluded from unwholesome mental qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which consists of joy and bliss born of seclusion and is accompanied by movement of the mind.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.3_0: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.4_0: Through the fading away of joy, I remained even-minded, mindful, and fully aware, experiencing bliss directly, and I entered and remained in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.5_0: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.6_0: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.1_0: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.2_0: I recollected many kinds of past lives.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.3_0: one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, and many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, and many eons of both dissolution and evolution, and I knew:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.4_0: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.5_0: passing away from there I arose in another state of existence,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.6_0: and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.7_0: When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.8_0: I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.9_0: This was the first true insight attained by me in the first part of the night.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.10_0: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.11_0: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.12_0: This, brahmin, was my first breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.1_0: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.2_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.3_0: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.4_0: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.5_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.6_0: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.7_0: They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they acted out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.8_0: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.9_0: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.10_0: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.11_0: This, brahmin, was my second breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.1_0: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.2_0: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.'
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.3_0: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.4_0: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.5_0: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.6_0: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.7_0: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.8_0: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.9_0: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.10_0: This, brahmin, was my third breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.1_0: That brahmin then said to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.2_0: “Master Gotama is the eldest! Master Gotama is the best!
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.4_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.5_0: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.6_0: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.7_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.8_0: And please consent to spend the rainy-season residence at Verañjā together with the Order of monks.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.9_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.10_0: He then got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.1_0: Now at that time enemies were short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw, and it was not easy to get by on almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.2_0: Just then some horse-dealers from Uttarāpatha had entered the rainy-season residence at Verañjā with five hundred horses.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.3_0: In the horse-pen they prepared many portions of steamed grain for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.4_0: After robing up, the monks took their bowls and robes and entered Koṇḍañña for alms, in the morning, and they ate the carrying net, mixed the requisites, and ate it. After eating their bending it, they made a wish,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.5_0: Venerable Ānanda crushed a portion of steamed grain on a stone, took it to the Buddha, and the Buddha ate it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.6_0: The Buddha heard the sound of his suffering,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.7_0: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.8_0: they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.9_0: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.10_0: by the Realized Ones are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.11_0: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.12_0: And so the Buddha said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, what’s this sound of a mortar?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.15_0: You who are superior people have conquered the problems of famine; later generations will despise even rice and meat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.1_0: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.1_2: and told him all that had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.2_0: “At present, Venerable Sir, Verañjā is short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.3_0: and it was not easy to get by on almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.4_0: Sir, the under-surface of this great earth is abounding with food, which tastes just like pure honey.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.5_0: It would be good if I swapped the monks from the ground and ate the water.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.6_0: “But Moggallāna, how could you do such a thing?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.7_0: “Sir, I shall climb the earth like a great earth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.7_1: I will build here the grounds there in the earth,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.8_0: Then with the other hand I’ll invert the earth.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.9_0: “Let it be, Moggallāna, please don’t invert the earth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.10_0: Those creatures might lose their minds.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.11_0: “In that case, Sir, it would be good if the whole Sangha of monks could go to Uttarakuru for alms.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.12_0: “Let it be, Moggallāna, please don’t pursue this.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.1_0: While he was in seclusion, he thought,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.2_0: “For which Buddhas did the spiritual life not last long?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.3_0: Which of these Buddhas did the spiritual life established by Buddhas?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.4_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.5_0: “Just now, Sir, while I was in seclusion, I thought,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.6_0: ‘For which Buddhas did the spiritual life not last long? What was the spiritual life lasting long?’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.6_1: Which of these Buddhas did the spiritual life not last long? What was their last long?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.7_0: “Sāriputta, the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū didn’t last long.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.8_0: But the spiritual life established by Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa did last long.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.1_0: “What is the reason, sir, what is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.2_0: “Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū were disinclined to give detailed teachings to their disciples.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.3_0: They gave few discourses in prose and in prose and verse, few expositions, verses, inspired exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.4_0: and they didn’t lay down training rules or recite a monastic code.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.5_0: After the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, clans, and social standing, who had gone forth from various families—allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.6_0: Suppose there was a fruit that was covered with various soups and fresh, covered and threwed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.8_0: Because they’re not held together by a string.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.9_0: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.10_0: But those Buddhas were untiring in instructing their disciples after reading their minds.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.11_0: At one time, Sāriputta, while staying in a certain frightening forest grove, Buddha Vessabhū, the Perfected and the fully Awakened One, instructed an sangha of a thousand monks, reading their minds and saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.13_0: pay attention like this, not like this;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.15_0: When those thousand monks had been instructed by Buddha Vessabhū, their minds were freed from the corruptions without grasping.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.16_0: But when anyone with sensual desire entered that frightening forest grove, usually their hair would stand on end.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.17_0: This is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū didn’t last long.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.1_0: “What then is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa lasted long?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.2_0: “Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa were diligent in giving detailed teachings to their disciples.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.3_0: They gave many discourses in prose and in prose and verse, many expositions, verses, inspired exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.4_0: and they laid down training rules and recited a monastic code.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.5_0: After the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, clans, and social standing, who had gone forth from various families—made that spiritual life last for a long time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.6_0: Suppose there was a fruit that was covered with many soles and well thread, and doesn’t smooth out.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.8_0: Because they are held together by a string.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.9_0: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.1_0: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, it’s the custom for Buddhas not to go wandering in the country without taking leave of those who invited them to spend the rainy-season residence.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.2_0: Come, Ānanda, let’s look at Verañja in the brahmin Verañjā.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.4_0: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe and, with Venerable Ānanda as his attendant, went to that brahmin’s house where he was born.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.4_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.5_0: Then the brahmin approached the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.6_0: And the Buddha said, “Brahmin, we’ve completed the rains residence according to your invitation, and now we take leave of you.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.7_0: We wish to depart to go wandering in the country.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.8_0: “It’s true, good Gotama, that you’ve completed the rains residence according to my invitation, but I haven’t given a gift.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.11_0: Would Master Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.1_0: At one time in Vesālī there was a village called Kapilavatthu.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.1_1: Herein, Sudinna’s son was named Sudinna’s son.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.2_0: On one occasion Sudinna went to Vesālī on some business together with a number of friends.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.3_0: On one occasion when the Buddha was seated teaching a large gathering,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.4_0: where he saw the Buddha teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.4_1: He thought, “Why don’t I listen to the teaching?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.5_0: He then approached that gathering and sat down.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.6_0: As he was sitting there, he thought,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.7_0: “As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.8_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.9_0: When those people had been instructed, inspired, and gladdened by the Buddha, they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated him with their right side toward him, and left.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.10_0: Sudinna then approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.10_2: and told him what was happening.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.11_0: “Venerable Sir, the way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.12_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.13_0: May the Buddha please give me the going forth.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.14_0: “But, Sudinna, do you have your parents’ permission?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.15_0: “Sir, I haven’t allowed my parents to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.16_0: “The Buddhas don’t give the going forth to the child of parents who haven’t given their permission.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.1.17_0: “I’ll do whatever is necessary, Sir, to get my parents’ permission.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.4.14_0: May the Buddha please give me the going forth.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.4.15_0: He then received the going forth in the presence of the Buddha, and he received the full ordination.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.4.16_0: Not long afterwards he practiced these kinds of ascetic practices: he stayed in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, was a rag-robe wearer, and went on continuous almsround.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.4.17_0: And he lived supported by a certain Vajjian village.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.1_0: At that time the Vajjians were short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw, and it was not easy to get by on almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.2_0: Venerable Sudinna considered this and thought,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.3_0: “I have many relatives in Vesālī who are rich.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.4_0: Why don’t I live supported by them?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.5_0: Because of me my relatives will be able to make offerings and make merit, the monks will get material support, and I’ll have no trouble getting almsfood.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.6_0: He then put his dwelling in order, took his bowl and robe and set out for Vesālī.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.5.7_1: where he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.3_0: “If that’s to be thrown away, sister, pour it here in my bowl.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.4_0: As she was pouring the porridge into his bowl, she recognized the features of his hands, feet, and voice.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.5_0: She then went to his mother and father.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.16_0: Sudinna’s father took him by the arm and said, “Come, let’s go to the house.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.17_0: Sudinna went to his father’s house and sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.18_0: His father said to him, “Eat, Sudinna.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.19_0: “There’s no need; I’ve finished eating for today.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.20_0: “Then please come back for the meal tomorrow.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.21_0: Sudinna consented by keeping silent, and he got up from his seat and left.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.6.25_0: “Now please adorn yourself in the way our son Sudinna found you especially attractive.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:5.7.1_0: Then, after robing up, Venerable Sudinna took his bowl and robe and went to his father’s house.
